quote.text: He who has overcome his fears will truly be free.
quote.author: Aristotle
quote.reference: Quoted in Florilegium by Joannes Stobaeus

quote.text: In all things of nature there is something of the marvelous.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: Misfortune shows those who are not really friends.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: Time crumbles things; everything grows old under the power of Time and is forgotten through the lapse of Time.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: It is absurd to hold that a man ought to be ashamed of being unable to defend himself with his limbs but not of being unable to defend himself with speech and reason, when the use of reason is more distinctive of a human being than the use of his limbs.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: Thus every action must be due to one or other of seven causes: chance, nature, compulsion, habit, reasoning, anger, or appetite.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: The young have exalted notions, because they have not been humbled by life or learned its necessary limitations; moreover, their hopeful disposition makes them think themselves equal to great thingsâ€”and that means having exalted notions. They would always rather do noble deeds than useful ones: Their lives are regulated more by moral feeling than by reasoning.... All their mistakes are in the direction of doing things excessively and vehemently. They overdo everything; they love too much, hate too much, and the same with everything else.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: It is simplicity that makes the uneducated more effective than the educated when addressing popular audiences.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: Man is by nature a political animal.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: Nature does nothing uselessly.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: Man, when perfected, is the best of animals, but when separated from law and justice, he is the worst of all.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: Money was intended to be used in exchange, but not to increase at interest. And this term interest, which means the birth of money from money, is applied to the breeding of money because the offspring resembles the parent. Wherefore of all modes of getting wealth this is the most unnatural.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: It is of the nature of desire not to be satisfied, and most men live only for the gratification of it.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: If liberty and equality, as is thought by some, are chiefly to be found in democracy, they will be best attained when all persons alike share in the government to the utmost.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: Well begun is half done.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: The basis of a democratic state is liberty.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: Happiness, whether consisting in pleasure or virtue, or both, is more often found with those who are highly cultivated in their minds and in their character, and have only a moderate share of external goods, than among those who possess external goods to a useless extent but are deficient in higher qualities.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: Law is order, and good law is good order.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: All men by nature desire to know. An indication of this is the delight we take in our senses; for even apart from their usefulness they are loved for themselves; and above all others the sense of sight. For not only with a view to action, but even when we are not going to do anything, we prefer sight to almost everything else. The reason is that this, most of all the senses, makes us know and brings to light many differences between things.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: If, then, God is always in that good state in which we sometimes are, this compels our wonder; and if in a better this compels it yet more. And God is in a better state. And life also belongs to God; for the actuality of thought is life, and God is that actuality; and God's self-dependent actuality is life most good and eternal.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: The single harmony produced by all the heavenly bodies singing and dancing together springs from one source and ends by achieving one purpose, and has rightly bestowed the name not of "disordered" but of "ordered universe" upon the whole.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: The life of money-making is one undertaken under compulsion, and wealth is evidently not the good we are seeking; for it is merely useful and for the sake of something else.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: Piety requires us to honor truth above our friends.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: For the things we have to learn before we can do, we learn by doing.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: Any one can get angry â€” that is easy â€” or give or spend money; but to do this to the right person, to the right extent, at the right time, with the right motive, and in the right way, that is not for every one, nor is it easy.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: We must as second best, as people say, take the least of the evils.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: Without friends no one would choose to live, though he had all other goods.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: With regard to excellence, it is not enough to know, but we must try to have and use it.
quote.author: Aristotle

quote.text: Liars when they speak the truth are not believed.
quote.author: Aristotle
